passages.text: BFB reiterated its FY26 guidance for -LSD OSG and organic operating profit.

We knew there could well be some noise associated with the route-to-market changes in the US, but the shipment timing dynamics in F1Q proved larger than expected as the late summer JD Blackberry launch also influenced distributor inventories. And, while the pull-forward into F1Q sets up another noisy quarter for F2Q, we feel comfortable with the notion of the full-year outlook holding steady with what was discussed in June - supported in part by continued momentum in emerging markets offsetting incremental softness in developed markets vs. what we previously contemplated.
BFb: Quarterly and Annual EPS (USD)

What to do with the stock: We were frankly somewhat surprised by the degree of FBF's underperformance yesterday (- 4.9% vs. XLP - 0.6%), given there was once again very little to signal emerging cracks in the health of FBF's core brand equities, and messaging regarding the consumer and industry backdrop struck us as largely unchanged vs. early June. In this vein, the

reiterated - LSD organic sups and profit guidance ranges struck us as reasonable. We now have a better grasp on the quarrly noise that is expected to be largely resolved by the end of F1H, while our full- year consotated outlook is unchanged vs. where we were heading into the print. And, while we recognize there is still an uphill battle in developed markets, we remain intrigued by what's to come in the up and the strong momentum in the emerging market footprint.

F1H is indeed proving noisy, and there are surely some puts and takes across the portfolio, but the full- year big picture outlook appears largely on track, in our view. We recognized there was likely to be some noise over F1H as BFB transitioned to its 7 new distributor partners across 14 markets beginning in August, which recall is the first major route- to- market revamp in over 60 years - although there was no real visibility in advance into how big of an impact this would ultimately have on F1Q. What we think was perhaps less contemplated by the market was the degree to which the JD Blackberry launch would also influence shipment timing. Ultimately, the two factors translated to a 6- point shipment tailwind to the US in the first quarter. Stripping this away, depletions- based US OSG of \(- 8\%\) lagged our - MSD expectation for the quarter; however, we'd note there was evidently some RTM- transition- related noise on depletion- based results as well, with instances of takeaways ahead of depletions in certain markets. To be sure, the underlying US performance represents a soft start to the year, but we're interested to see what the increased focus and dedicated salesforce tied to the the RTM changes, along with the JD Blackberry innovation, can do for domestic trends looking ahead. And importantly, the FY26 guide assumes a largely steady consumer environment through the balance of the year.

At a total company level, shipments of \(+6\%\) (and OSG of \(+1\%\) ) benefited from a 4- point favorable distributor inventory change. BFB expects this shipment timing to normalize in 2Q (we now embed a \(- 3.5\%\) drag to F2Q shipment- based OSG), with our F2QE shipment- based OSG now \(- 6\%\) (from \(- 2.5\%\) previously). But looking at depletions- based OSG to smooth out this noise, we still remain comfortable with the notion of diminishing - LSD declines across FY26. And our FY26 OSG is unchanged at \(- 2.1\%\) (vs. BFB's reiterated - LSD guide) as we still expect robust emerging market growth to help offset softer results in developed markets.

We think emerging markets are often an overlooked aspect of the BFB story, but the F1Q print makes a strong case for why that shouldn't be the case. BFB's FY26 - LSD OSG guide assumes declines in developed markets are partially offset by growth in emerging markets, and the latter posted an especially robust start to the year. Even excluding a \(+10\%\) tailwind from shipment timing (driven by some UAE laps and intentional inventory rebuild in Paraguay and Uruguay), the EM depletions- based OSG was an impressive \(+15\%\) . To be sure, emerging markets have been a solid growth contributor for several years (including, most recently, +HSD shipment- based OSG or +MSD depletion- based OSG in FY25) - and yet, this side of the footprint seems to receive notably less airtime in our BFB conversations.

On one hand, we can understand that there's a debate to be had as to what an investor wants to pay for emerging market growth vs. developed market growth. On the other hand, the emerging footprint continues to (over)deliver for BFB, and we'd argue it warrants more attention. And indeed, this seems to be the case internally (if not yet by the investment community), given CEO Lawson Whiting's comments during yesterday's conference call that the business is allocating more resources to emerging markets. Healthy levels of support behind these markets are all the more crucial at a time when US and developed international growth remains challenged, and Mr. Whiting acknowledged the difficulty in forecasting the recovery for those markets (e.g. while the view is that there is still growth to be had, he refrained from opining specifically on if/when the US spirits industry returns to \(+4 - 5\%\) growth).

In terms of specific focus areas, Brazil remains a standout (F1Q OSG +39%), and we were especially intrigued to hear Mr. Whiting flag the growing premiumization strategy for this market (i.e. increasing distribution for Woodford Reserve, JD Single Barrel and Gentleman Jack). Other key markets called out included Turkiye (where the premium whiskey market had been a consistent driver over the last few years), UAE and India. BFB will also continue to support Mexico, where the macro backdrop remains challenged, but BFB is gaining share within the RTD and whiskey categories. We also believe JD Blackberry will reflect another avenue for growth in emerging markets (much like we've seen BFB thoughtfully layer in the other flavor extensions in Brazil), although this will surely be a long-term journey.

Changes to model. We remain anchored to \(- 2.1\%\) OSG and \(\) 1.64\(EPS in FY26, but we've made some updates with respect to the moving pieces that get us there. From a topline perspective, we now look for - 2.3% price/mix and + 0.2% shipments, with the former revised down to better capture the mix headwinds of RTD outperformance and lower used barrel sales and the latter revised upwards driven mainly by the F1Q beat on shipments. Specific to F2Q, we model an incremental - 3.5% drag to shipments to reflect the unwind from favorable shipment timing in F1Q, now seeing F2Q shipment - based OSG as a low point for the year (- 6.0%) that migrates back to - LSD in F2He. From a geographic perspective, we still look for +MSD growth from emerging markets over the balance of the year, but flowing through the F1Q beat brings the full year to +9.9% (from +5.6%). In contrast, we now look for developed international organic sales to decline - 3.9% (from - 3.4%). The downside vs. our prior model stemmed mainly from western Europe, with partial offset from the drag associated with Canada actually easing vs. our prior model, given we now assume some growth in non - US brands in that market. Layering in a - 2.8% structural drag (which now includes some dwindling TSA laps through F3Q) and a +1.5% FX tailwind, we arrive at a - 3.5% net sales decline for the year.

Moving down the P&L, we look for - 100 bps of gross margin expansion as cost pressures (driven by margin dilution from softer used barrel sales along with operating de- leverage) are more than offset by the structural tailwind from the TSA and Korbel exits. Price/mix and FX are both roughly neutral for the year in our updated gross margin build. We look for SG&A and advertising declines that both slightly outpace the organic sales decline, which brings SG&A to 18.6% of sales and advertising to 12.4% of sales. Our operating margin is now up +110 bps YoY to 29.0% (vs. 28.6% previously), with the difference driven by a \(\) 18\$ mm substitution drawback claim collection that came through F1Q. Our FY26 organic operating profit forecast is situated towards the low end of BFB's - LSD range. We continue to model interest expense near - \(\) 90\$ mm (now \(\) 89\$ mm) and a tax rate towards the midpoint BFB's 21- 23% guide (now 22.2% after flowing through the F1QA ETR). All in, we reiterate our FY26 EPS forecast of \(\) 1.64\$ .

We lower our price target to \(\) 32\(to reflect movement in peer multiples. Our new price target is predicated on a - 18.3x target P/E multiple (largely in - line with Large - Cap Staples) on our CY26 EPS estimate of\) \ \(1.73\) . Our prior \(\) 33\(price target was based on a - 18.8x target P/E multiple (also largely in - line with LC Staples) on our prior CY26 EPS estimate of\) \ \(1.73\) .

Overweight - The stock is expected to outperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Equal Weight - The stock is expected to perform in line with the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Underweight - The stock is expected to underperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Positive - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are improving.
Neutral - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are steady, neither improving nor deteriorating.
Negative - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are deteriorating.

*This is the closing price referenced in the publication, which may not be the last available closing price at the time of publication.
Historical stock prices and price targets may have been adjusted for stock splits and dividends.
**Valuation Methodology:** Our $32 price target represents a ~18.3x P/E multiple on our CY26 EPS estimate of $1.73.

**Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target:** Risks to our thesis include more disruption to US spirits industry, less global demand for premium brown spirits than anticipated and/or slower adoption of emerging brands internationally, increased competition and industry fragmentation in the U.S. hurting the Jack Daniel's trademark domestically.
